The storage and handling of chlorine containers. The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA??A?s Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA??A?s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation. The process includes equipment to allow for transfil of silane from a full Isomodue (from current supplier REC) to a new empty APCI owned Isomodule until the pressures equalize.   The process is based on a A?tube to tubeA? equalization to allow for:
    1) Achieving the highest practical silane pressure in the new APCI units to meet REC conditions/agreement prior to them doing a fill of the APCI unit.

    2) Allow for passivation of the steel of the new tubes which will minimize future disilane and H2 evolution which are contaminants in high purity silane.

The location selected for this project is at the far end of RGT where the ISO modules will be spotted adjacent to each other (full and empty).

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary


Air Products and Chemicals, Inc.
Hometown Electronics Specialty Gases Facility

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Air Products manages the safety of the regulated processes by means of operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, shutdowns, instrumentation, relief devices) inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plant.

Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA??A?s HAZWOPER regulation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and Hazardous Materials unit so that appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to control accidental releases.

2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled:

The primary purpose of this facility is the production of specialty and electronic gases and chemicals.  A majority of these gases are derived from fluorine, which is generated at the site in electrolytic cells by electrical decomposition of hydrogen fluoride.  Hydrogen is generated as a by-product, which is vented in small amounts to the atmosphere.  The electrolysis takes place in a cell containing hydrogen fluoride with dissolved potassium bifluoride.  The majority of the fluorine is cooled by liquid nitrogen to remove residual hydrogen fluoride and potassium fluoride carried over from the electrolytic cells.  After these impurities are removed, the gas is compressed for distribution to the various fluorine users throughout the facility.

The hydrogen fluoride is brought on site by railcar that is placed inside a totally enclosed containment building for processing.  The hydrogen fluoride is then fed directly from the ra

ilcar to the fluorine plant or pumped into cylinders, which are stored and maintained on site for shipment to customers.  Additional railcars are stored outside of the building due to the increasing demand for the material.

This facility also re-packages anhydrous hydrogen chloride.  The hydrogen chloride is brought on site by railcar.  From the railcar, it is transferred through a series of heat exchangers and pumps to the tube trailers and cylinders.  Also, tube trailers and cylinder storage of hydrogen chloride are maintained.

Anhydrous ammonia is brought on site by tank truck and pumped into a stationary storage tank.  It is used as a raw material in the production of nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).  NF3 is made by introducing fluorine gas into ammonium bifluoride.  Ammonia is transferred under its own storage tank pressure, vaporized, and fed to the system to control the hydrogen fluoride concentration in the product, and to replenish the ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is also fed to a purification plant, where moisture is removed before it is re-packaged into other bulk containers. The packaged bulk containers are stored adjacent to the purification plant.

Hydrogen selenide is produced by the reduction/hydrogenation of pure (elemental) Selenium. The reaction takes place in a reactor and is carried out with an excess of hydrogen.  The resulting H2Se is removed from the gas stream by liquefaction into collectors.  From here, it is transferred into product cylinders, which are stored in our shipping/receiving area.

Arsine cylinders and chlorine containers are filled at other locations and are only stored in our shipping/receiving area.  Cylinders of boron trichloride which contain residual product are received from other sites and re-packaged into A-5 containers for resale or disposal.

Phosphine cylinders are are filled at other locations and are stored in our shipping/receiving area. Containers of trichlorosilane which contain residual product are rece

ived from customers and are re-packaged into 210 AC Containers for resale or disposal.

This resubmittal is the result of bringing an additional chemical on-site to prep bulk containers (tube trailers) for silane filling. The demand for silane has increased and the preferred method for use is from a tube trailer. Fleet size will increase which will result in more prep requirements. This work was previously done at another Air Products facility. The prep step and storage will occur in the same location on site.

The regulated substances handled at this facility are fluorine, hydrogen fluoride, anhydrous hydrogen chloride, anhydrous ammonia, arsine, boron trichloride, hydrogen selenide, chlorine, phosphine, trichlorosilane, and silane.  

3.  This update includes a revision to the arsine alternative case scenario (ACS), based on a more rigorous calculation of release rate and the amount in the cylinder.  It also includes an ACS for a hydrogen selenide cylinder that had its cylinder valve sheared off from being dropped during handling and an ACS from the failure of a safety device on a chlorine ton unit.

4.  The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA??A?s Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA??A?s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council??A?s Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state
specific regulatory requirements.  This update includes revisions to the prevention programs for all ten processes on site.

5.  Five-year accident history:

This facility came on line in March of 1973.  In the last five years, there have been three accidental releases: hydrogen fluoride (twice) and fluorine (one).  Each of these incidents resulted in a single injury to operating personnel on site.

6.  The emergency response program:

The facility complies

with all EPA, OSHA, and Compressed Gas Association requirements for emergency response. Employees that are members of the on-site emergency response team at the facility will respond to emergencies before initiating emergency response from outside agencies.  

The facility maintains an Emergency Procedure Manual that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release. This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencies.  

7.  Planned changes to improve safety:

The facility resolves recommendations from PHA??A?s and Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.  It also strives toward continuous improvement in regards to EH&S and good engineering practices and design. 

The facility implements the American Chemistry Council??A?s Responsible Care codes of management practices. In addition to this, Air Products and Chemicals has implemented EH&S Global standards and best practices that often exceed regulatory standards.
